verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:1
verses.text: Epistle LXIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:2
verses.text: Limenius, Bishop of Vercellae, having died, the see remained long vacant owing to domestic factions.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:3
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:4
verses.text: Ambrose, therefore, as Exarch, writes to the Christians at Vercellae, and commences by reference to the speedy and unanimous election of Eusebius, a former Bishop, and reminds them of the presence of Christ as a reason for concord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:5
verses.text: He refers next to two apostate monks, Sarmatio and Barbatianus, and inveighs against sensuality, which degrades men below the beasts.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:6
verses.text: Thence he passes to the virtues required in a bishop, referring again to Eusebius, and to Dionysius, Bishop of Milan, comparing the clerical and monastic lives, and ends with exhortations to Christian virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:7
verses.text: The letter seems to have been written a.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:10
verses.text: Ambrose, a servant of Christ, called to be a Bishop, to the Church of Vercellae, and to those who call on the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ, Grace be fulfilled unto you in the Holy Spirit from God the Father and His only-begotten Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:12
verses.text: I am spent with grief that the Church of God which is among you is still without a bishop, and now alone of all the regions of Liguria and aemilia, and of the Venetiae and other neighbouring parts of Italy needs that care which other churches were wont to ask for themselves from it; and what is a greater source of shame to myself, the tension amongst you which causes the obstacle is laid to my charge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:13
verses.text: Now since there are dissensions among you, how can we decree anything, or you elect, or anyone agree to undertake this office amongst those who are at variance which he could hardly sustain amongst those who are at unity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:15
verses.text: Is this the training of a confessor, are these the offspring of those righteous fathers who, as soon as they saw, approved of holy Eusebius, whom they had never known before, preferring him to their fellow-citizens, and he was no sooner amongst them than he was approved, and much more when they had observed him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:16
verses.text: Justly did he turn out so great a man, whom the whole Church elected, justly was it believed that he whom all had demanded was elected by the judgment of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:17
verses.text: It is fitting then that you follow the example of your parents, especially since you who have been instructed by a holy confessor ought to be so much better than your fathers, as a better teacher has taught and instructed you, and to manifest a sign of your moderation and concord by agreeing in your request for a Bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:19
verses.text: For if according to the Lord's saying, that which two shall have agreed upon on earth concerning anything which they shall ask, shall be done for them, as He says, by My Father, Who is in heaven, for: "Where two or three are gathered together in My Name, there am I in the midst of them," how much less, where the full congregation is gathered in the Name of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:20
verses.text: Where the demand of all is unanimous, ought we to doubt that the Lord Jesus is there as the Author of that desire, and the Hearer of the petition, the Presider over the ordination, and the Giver of the grace?  4.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:21
verses.text: Make yourselves then to appear worthy that Christ should be in your midst.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:22
verses.text: For where peace is, there is Christ, for Christ is Peace; and where righteousness is, there is Christ, for Christ is Righteousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:23
verses.text: Let Him be in the midst of you, that you may see Him, lest it be said to you also: "There standeth One in the midst of you, Whom ye see not".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:24
verses.text: The Jews saw not Him in Whom they believed not; we look upon Him by devotion, and behold Him by faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:26
verses.text: Let Him therefore stand in your midst, that the heavens, which declare the glory of God, may be opened to you, that you may do His will, and work His works.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:27
verses.text: He who sees Jesus, to him are the heavens opened as they were opened to Stephen, when he said: "Behold I see the heavens opened and Jesus standing at the right hand of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:28
verses.text: Jesus was standing as his advocate, He was standing as though anxious, that He might help His athlete Stephen in his conflict, He was standing as though ready to crown His martyr.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:30
verses.text: Let Him then be standing for you, that you may not be afraid of Him sitting; for when sitting He judges, as Daniel says: "The thrones were placed, and the books were opened, and the Ancient of days did sit".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:31
verses.text: But in the eighty-first [second] Psalm it is written: "God stood in the congregation of gods, and decideth among the gods".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:32
verses.text: So then when He sits He judges, when He stands He decides, and He judges concerning the imperfect, but decides among the gods.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:33
verses.text: Let Him stand for you as a defender, as a good shepherd, lest the fierce wolves assault you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:35
verses.text: And not in vain is my warning turned to this point; for I hear that Sarmatio and Barbatianus are come to you, foolish talkers,  who say that there is no merit in abstinence, no grace in a frugal life, none in virginity, that all are valued at one price, that they are mad who chasten their flesh with fastings, that they may bring it into subjection to the spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:36
verses.text: But if he had thought it madness, Paul the Apostle would never himself have acted thus, nor written to instruct others.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:37
verses.text: For he glories in it, saying: "But I chasten my body, and bring it into bondage, lest, after preaching to others, I myself should be found reprobate".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:38
verses.text: So they who do not chasten their body, and desire to preach to others, are themselves esteemed reprobates.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:40
verses.text: For is there anything so reprobate as that which excites to luxury, to corruption, to wantonness, as the incentive to lust, the enticer to pleasure, the fuel of incontinence, the firebrand of desire? What new school has sent out these Epicureans? Not a school of philosophers, as they themselves say, but of unlearned men who preach pleasure, persuade to luxury, esteem chastity to be of no use.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:41
verses.text: They were with us, but they were not of us, for we are not ashamed to say what the Evangelist John said.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:42
verses.text: But when settled here they used to fast at first, they were enclosed within the monastery, there was no place for luxury, the opportunity of mocking and disputing was cut off.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:44
verses.text: This these dainty men could not endure.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:45
verses.text: They went abroad, then when they desired to return they were not received; for I had heard many things which necessitated my being cautious; I admonished them, but effected nothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:46
verses.text: And so boiling over they began to disseminate such things as made them the miserable enticers to all vices.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:47
verses.text: They utterly lost the benefit of having fasted; they lost the fruits of their temporary continence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:48
verses.text: And so now they with Satanic eagerness envy the good works of others, the fruit of which themselves have failed to keep.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:50
verses.text: What virgin can hear that there is no reward for her chastity and not groan? Far be it from her to believe this easily, and still more to lay aside her zeal, or change the intention of her mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:51
verses.text: What widow, when she learnt that there was no profit in her widowhood, would choose to preserve her marriage faith and live in sorrow, rather than give herself up to a happier condition? Who, bound by the marriage-bond, if she hear that there is no honour in chastity, might not be tempted by careless levity of body or mind? And for this reason the Church in the holy lessons, and in the addresses of her priests, proclaims the praise of chastity and the glory of virginity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:53
verses.text: In vain, then, does the Apostle say: "I wrote to you, in an Epistle, not to mingle with fornicators;" and lest perchance they should say, We are not speaking of all the fornicators of the world, but we say that he who has been baptized in Christ ought not now to be esteemed a fornicator, but his life, whatever it is, is accepted of God, the Apostle has added "Not at all [meaning] with the fornicators of this world," and farther on, "If any that is named a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolator, or a reviler, or a drunkard, or an extortioner, with such an one not even to eat.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:54
verses.text: For what have I to do with judging them that are without?" And to the Ephesians: "But fornication, and all uncleanness, and covetousness let it not even be named among you, as becometh saints".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:55
verses.text: And immediately he adds: "For this ye know, that no immodest person, nor unclean, nor covetous, which is an idolator, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:56
verses.text: It is clear that this is said of the baptized, for they receive the inheritance, who are baptized into the death of Christ and are buried together with Him, that they may rise again with Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:57
verses.text: Therefore they are heirs of God, and joint heirs with Christ: heirs of God, because the grace of Christ is conveyed to them; joint-heirs with Christ, because they are renewed into His life; heirs also of Christ; because to them is given by His death as it were the inheritance of the testator.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:59
verses.text: These then ought to take heed to themselves who have that which they may lose, rather than they who have it not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:60
verses.text: These ought to act with greater care, these ought to guard against the allurements of vice, or incentives to error, which arise chiefly from food and drink.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:61
verses.text: For "the people sat down to eat and drink, and rose up to play".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:63
verses.text: Epicurus himself also, whom these persons think they should follow rather than the apostles, the advocate of pleasure, although he denies that pleasure brings in evil, does not deny that certain things result from it from which evils are generated; and asserts in fine that the life of the luxurious which is filled with pleasures does not seem to be reprehensible, unless it be disturbed by the fear either of pain or of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:64
verses.text: But  how far he is from the truth is perceived even from this, that he asserts that pleasure was originally created in man by God its author, as Philomarus his follower argues in his Epitomae, asserting that the Stoics are the authors of this opinion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:66
verses.text: But Holy Scripture refutes this, for it teaches us that pleasure was suggested to Adam and Eve by the craft and enticements of the serpent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:67
verses.text: Since, indeed, the serpent itself is pleasure, and therefore the passions of pleasure are various and slippery, and as it were infected with the poison of corruptions, it is certain then that Adam, being deceived by the desire of pleasure, fell away from the commandment of God and from the enjoyment of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:68
verses.text: How then can pleasure recall us to paradise, seeing that it alone deprived us of it?  15.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:69
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord Jesus, wishing to make us more strong against the temptations of the devil, fasted when about to contend with him, that we might know that we can in no other way overcome the enticements of evil.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:70
verses.text: Further, the devil himself hurled the first dart of his temptations from the quiver of pleasure, saying: "If Thou be the Son of God, command that these stones become bread".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:71
verses.text: After which the Lord said: "Man doth not live by bread alone, but by every word of God;" and would not do it, although He could, in order to teach us by a salutary precept to attend rather to the pursuit of reading than to pleasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:72
verses.text: And since they say that we ought not to fast, let them prove for what cause Christ fasted, unless it were that His fast might be an example to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:73
verses.text: Lastly, in His later words He taught us that evil cannot be easily overcome except by our fasting, saying: "This kind of devils is not cast out but by prayer and fasting".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:75
verses.text: And what is the intention of the Scripture which teaches us that Peter fasted, and that the revelation concerning the baptism of Gentiles was made to him when fasting and praying, except to show that the Saints themselves advance when they fast.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:76
verses.text: Finally, Moses received the Law when he was fasting; and so Peter when fasting was taught the grace of the New Testament.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:77
verses.text: Daniel too by virtue of his fast stopped the mouths of the lions and saw the events of future times.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:78
verses.text: And what safety can there be for us unless we wash away our sins by fasting, since Scripture says that fasting and alms do away sin?  17.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:79
verses.text: Who then are these new teachers who reject the merit of fasting? Is it not the voice of heathen who say, "Let us eat and drink?" whom the Apostle well ridicules, when he says: "If after the manner of men I have fought with beasts at Ephesus, what advantageth it me if the dead rise not? Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:80
verses.text: That is to say, What profited me my contention even unto death, except that I might redeem my body? And it is redeemed in vain if there is no hope of the resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:81
verses.text: And, consequently, if all hope of the resurrection is lost, let us eat and drink, let us not lose the enjoyment of things present, who have none of things to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:82
verses.text: It is then for them to indulge in meats and drinks who hope for nothing after death.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:84
verses.text: Rightly then does the Apostle, arguing against these men, warn us that we be not shaken by such opinions, saying: "Be not deceived, evil communications corrupt good manners.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:85
verses.text: Be ye righteously sober and sin not, for some have no knowledge of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:86
verses.text: Sobriety, then, is good, for drunkenness is sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:88
verses.text: But as to that Epicurus himself, the defender of pleasure, of whom, therefore, we have made frequent mention in order to prove that these men are either disciples of the heathen and followers of the Epicurean sect or himself, whom the very philosophers exclude from their company as the patron of luxury, what if we prove him to be more tolerable than these men? He declares, as Demarchus asserts, that neither drinking, nor banquets, nor offspring, nor embraces of women, nor abundance of fish, and other such like things which are prepared for the service of a sumptuous banquet, make life sweet, but sober discussion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:89
verses.text: Lastly, he added that those who do not use the banquets of society in excess, use them with moderation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:90
verses.text: He who willingly makes use of the juices of plants alone together with bread and water, despises feasts on delicacies, for many inconveniences arise from them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:91
verses.text: In another place they also say: It is not excessive banquets, nor drinking which give rise to the enjoyment of pleasure, but a life of temperance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:93
verses.text: Since, then, philosophy has disowned those men, is the Church not to exclude them? Seeing, too, that they, because they  have a bad cause, frequently fall foul of themselves by their own assertions.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:94
verses.text: For, although their chief opinion is that there is no enjoyment of pleasure except such as is derived from eating and drinking, yet understanding that they cannot, without the greatest shame, cling to so disgraceful a definition, and that they are forsaken by all, they have tried to colour it with a sort of stain of specious arguments; so that one of them has said: Whilst we are aiming at pleasure by means of banquets and songs, we have lost that which is infused into us by the reception of the Word, whereby alone we can be saved.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:96
verses.text: Do not they by these various arguments show themselves to us as differing and disagreeing one with the other? And Scripture too condemns them, not passing over those whom the Apostle refuted, as Luke, who wrote the book as a history, tells us in the Acts of the Apostles, "And certain also of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers disputed with him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:97
verses.text: And some said, What does this babbler mean? And others said, He seemeth to be a setter forth of new gods".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:99
verses.text: Yet from this hand too the Apostle did not go forth without success, since even Dionysius the Areopagite together with his wife Damaris and many others believed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:100
verses.text: And so that company of most learned and eloquent men showed themselves overcome in a simple discussion by the example of those who believed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:101
verses.text: What then do those men mean, who endeavour to prevent those whom the Apostle has gained, and whom Christ has redeemed with His own blood? asserting that the baptized ought not to give themselves to the discipline of the virtues, that revellings injure them not, nor abundance of pleasures; that they are foolish who go without them, that virgins ought to marry, bear children, and likewise widows to repeat that converse with man which they have once experienced with ill results; and that even if they can contain, they are in error who will not again enter the marriage bond.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:103
verses.text: What then? Would you have us put off the man in order to put on the beast, and stripping ourselves of Christ, clothe ourselves or be superclothed with the garments of the devil? But since the very teachers of the heathen did not think that honour and pleasure could be joined together, because they would seem thus to class beasts with men, shall we as it were infuse the habits of beasts into the human breast, and inscribe on the reasonable mind the unreasoning ways of wild beasts?  24.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:104
verses.text: And yet there are many kinds of animals, which, when they have lost their fellow, will not mate again, and spend their time as it were in solitary life; many too live on simple herbs, and will not quench their thirst except at a pure stream; one can also often see dogs refrain from food forbidden them, so that they close their famishing mouths if restraint is bidden them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:105
verses.text: Must men then be warned against that wherein brutes have learned not to transgress?  26.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:106
verses.text: But what is more admirable than abstinence, which makes even the years of youth to ripen, so that there is an old age of character? For as by excess of food and by drunkenness even mature age is excited, so the wildness of youth is lessened by scanty feasts and by the running stream.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:107
verses.text: An external fire is extinguished by pouring on water, it is then no wonder if the inward heat of the body is cooled by draughts from the stream, for the flame is fed or fails according to the fuel.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:108
verses.text: As hay, straw, wood, oil, and such like things are the nourishment which feeds fire, if you take them away, or do not supply them, the fire is extinguished.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:109
verses.text: In like manner then the heat of the body is supported or lessened by food, it is excited by food and lessened by food.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:110
verses.text: Luxury then is the mother of lust.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:112
verses.text: And is not temperance agreeable to nature, and to that divine law, which in the very beginning of all created things gave the springs for drink and the fruits of the trees for food? After the Flood the just man found wine a source of temptation to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:113
verses.text: Let us then use the natural drink of temperance, and would that we all were able to do so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:114
verses.text: But because all are not strong the Apostle said: "Use a little wine because of thy frequent infirmities".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:115
verses.text: We must drink it then not for the sake of pleasure, but because of infirmity, and therefore sparingly as a remedy, not in excess as a gratification.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:117
verses.text: Lastly, Elijah, whom the Lord was training to the perfection of virtue, found at his head a cake and a cruse of water; and then fasted in the strength of that food forty days and forty nights.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:118
verses.text: Our fathers, when they passed across the sea on foot, drank water not wine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:119
verses.text: Daniel and the Hebrew children, fed with their peculiar food, and with water to drink, overcame, the former the fury of the lions; the latter saw the  burning fire play around their limbs with harmless touch.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:121
verses.text: And why should I speak of men? Judith, in no way moved by the luxurious banquet of Holophernes, carried off the triumph of which men's arms despaired, solely in right of her temperance; delivered her country from occupation and slew the leader of the expedition with her own hands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:122
verses.text: A clear proof both that his luxury had enervated that warrior, terrible to the nations, and that temperance made this woman stronger than men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:123
verses.text: In this case it was not in her sex that nature was surpassed, but she overcame by her diet.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:124
verses.text: Esther by her fasts moved a proud king.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:125
verses.text: Anna, who for eighty-four years in her widowhood had served God with fasts and prayers day and night in the temple, recognized Christ, Whom John, the master of abstinence, and as it were a new angel on earth, announced.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:127
verses.text: O foolish Elisha, for feeding the prophets with wild and bitter gourds! O Ezra forgetful of Scripture, though he did restore the Scriptures from memory! foolish Paul, who glories in fastings, if fastings profit nothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:129
verses.text: But how should that not be profitable by which our sins are purged? And if you offer this with humility and with mercy, your bones, as Isaiah said, shall be fat, and you shall be like a well-watered garden.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:130
verses.text: So, then, your soul shall grow fat and its virtues also by the spiritual richness of fasting, and your fruits shall be multiplied by the fertility of your mind, so that there may be in you the inebriation of soberness, like that cup of which the Prophet says: "Thy cup which inebriates, how excellent it is!"  32.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:131
verses.text: But not only is that temperance worthy of praise which moderates food, but also that which moderates lust.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:132
verses.text: Since it is written: "Go not after thy lusts, and deny thy appetite.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:133
verses.text: If thou givest her desires to thy soul, thou wilt be a joy to thine enemies;" and farther on; "Wine and women make even wise men to fall away".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:134
verses.text: So that Paul teaches temperance even in marriage itself; for he who is incontinent in marriage is a kind of adulterer, and violates the law of the Apostle.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:136
verses.text: And why should I tell how great is the grace of virginity, which was found worthy to be chosen by Christ, that it might be even the bodily temple of God, in which as we read the fulness of the Godhead dwelt bodily.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:137
verses.text: A Virgin conceived the Salvation of the world, a Virgin brought forth the life of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:138
verses.text: Virginity then ought not to be left to itself, seeing that it benefited all in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:139
verses.text: A Virgin bore Him Whom this world cannot contain or support.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:140
verses.text: And when He was born from His mother's womb, He yet preserved the fence of her chastity and the inviolate seal of her virginity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:141
verses.text: And so Christ found in the Virgin that which He willed to make His own, that which the Lord of all might take to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:142
verses.text: Further, our flesh was cast out of Paradise by a man and woman and was joined to God through a Virgin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:144
verses.text: What shall I say concerning the other Mary, the sister of Moses, who as leader of the women passed on foot the straits of the sea? By the same gift Thecla also was reverenced by the lions, so that the unfed beasts stretched at the feet of their prey prolonged a holy fast, and harmed the virgin neither with wanton look nor claw, since virginity is injured even by a look.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:146
verses.text: Again, with what reverence for virginity has the holy Apostle spoken: "Concerning virgins I have no commandment of the Lord, but I give my counsel, as having obtained mercy of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:147
verses.text: He has received no commandment, but a counsel, for that which beyond the law is not commanded, but is rather advised by way of counsel.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:148
verses.text: Authority is not assumed but grace is shown, and this is not shown by anyone, but by him who obtained mercy from the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:149
verses.text: Are then the counsels of these men better than those of the apostles? The Apostle says, "I give my counsel," but they think it right to dissuade any from cultivating virginity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:151
verses.text: And we ought to recognize what commendation of it the prophet, or rather Christ in the prophet, has uttered in a short verse; "A garden enclosed," says He, "is My sister, My spouse, a garden enclosed, a sealed fountain".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:152
verses.text: Christ says this to the Church, which he desires to be a virgin, without spot, without a wrinkle.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:153
verses.text: A fertile garden is virginity, which can bear many fruits of good odour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:154
verses.text: A garden enclosed, because it is everywhere shut in by the wall of chastity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:155
verses.text: A sealed fountain, because virginity is the source and origin of modesty, having to keep inviolate the seal of purity, in which source the image of God is reflected, since the purity of simplicity agrees also with chastity of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:157
verses.text: And no one can doubt that the Church is a virgin, who also in the Epistle to the Corinthians is espoused and presented as a chaste virgin to Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:158
verses.text: So in the first Epistle he gives his counsel, and esteems the gift of virginity as good, since it is not disturbed by any troubles of the present time, nor polluted by any of its defilements, nor shaken by any storms; in the later Epistle he brings a spouse to Christ, because he is able to certify the virginity of the Church in the purity of that people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:160
verses.text: Answer me now, O Paul, in what way thou givest counsel for the present distress.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:161
verses.text: "Because he that is without a wife is careful," he says, "for the things of the Lord, how he may please God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:162
verses.text: And he adds, "The unmarried woman and the virgin think of the things of the Lord, that they may be holy in body and spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:163
verses.text: She has then her wall against the tempests of this world, and so fortified by the defence of divine protection she is disturbed by none of the blasts of this world.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:164
verses.text: Good then is counsel, because there is advantage in counsel, but there is a bond in a commandment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:165
verses.text: Counsel attracts the willing, commandment binds the unwilling.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:166
verses.text: If then anyone has followed counsel, and not repented, she has gained an advantage; but if she has repented, she has no ground for blaming the Apostle, for she ought herself to have judged of her own weakness; and so she is responsible for her own will, inasmuch as she bound herself by a bond and knot beyond her power to bear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:168
verses.text: And so like a good physician, desiring to preserve the stability of virtue in the strong, and to give health to the weak, he gives counsel to the one, and points out the remedy to the others: "He that is weak eateth herbs," let him take a wife; he that has more power let him seek the stronger meat of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:169
verses.text: And rightly he added: "For he who being steadfast hath settled in his own heart, having no necessity, but hath power over his own will, and hath determined this in his own heart, to keep his own virgin, doeth well.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:170
verses.text: So then both he who giveth his own virgin in marriage, doeth well; and he that giveth her not in marriage, doeth better.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:171
verses.text: A woman is bound by the law, for so long a time as her husband liveth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:172
verses.text: But if her husband have fallen asleep, she is freed, let her marry whom she will, only in the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:173
verses.text: But she will be more happy if she abide as she is, after my counsel, for I think that I also have the Spirit of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:174
verses.text: This is to have the counsel of God, to search diligently into all things, and to advise things that are best, and to point out those that are safest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:176
verses.text: A careful guide points out many paths, that each may walk along the one which he prefers and considers suitable to himself, so long as he comes upon one by which he can reach the camp.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:177
verses.text: The path of virginity is good, but being high and steep requires the stronger wayfarers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:178
verses.text: Good also is that of widowhood, not so difficult as the former, but being rocky and rough, it requires more cautious travellers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:179
verses.text: Good too is that of marriage; being smooth and even it reaches the camp of the saints by a longer circuit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:180
verses.text: This way is taken by most.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:181
verses.text: There are then the rewards of virginity, there are the merits of widowhood, there is also a place for conjugal modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:182
verses.text: There are steps and advances in each and every virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:184
verses.text: Stand therefore firm in your hearts, that no one overthrow you, that no one be able to make you fall.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:185
verses.text: The Apostle has taught us what it is "to stand," that is what was said to Moses: "The place whereon thou standest is holy ground;" for no one stands unless he stand by faith, unless he stands fixed in the determination of his own heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:186
verses.text: In another place also we read: "But do thou stand here with Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:187
verses.text: Each sentence was spoken by the Lord to Moses, both "Where thou standest is holy ground," and "Stand here with Me," that is, thou standest with Me, if thou stand firm in the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:188
verses.text: For the very place is holy, the very ground is fruitful with sanctity and fertile with harvests of virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:190
verses.text: Stand then in the Church, stand where I appeared to thee, where I am with thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:191
verses.text: Where the Church is, there is the most solid resting place for thy mind, there the support of thy soul, where I appeared to thee in the bush.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:192
verses.text: Thou art the bush, I am the fire; the fire in the bush, I in the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:193
verses.text: Therefore am I the fire, that I may give light to thee, that I may consume thy thorns, that is, thy sins, and show thee My grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:195
verses.text: Standing firm then in your hearts, drive away from the Church the wolves which seek to carry off prey.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:196
verses.text: Let there be no sloth in you, let not your mouth be evil nor your tongue bitter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:197
verses.text: Do not sit in the council of vanity; for it is written, "I have not sat in the council of vanity".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:198
verses.text: Do not listen to those who speak against their neighbours,  lest whilst you listen to others, you be stirred up yourselves to speak against your neighbours, and it be said to each of you: "Thou satest and spakest against thy brother".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:200
verses.text: Men sit when speaking against others, they stand when they praise the Lord, to whom it is said: "Behold now, praise the Lord, all ye servants of the Lord, ye that stand in the house of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:201
verses.text: He who sits, to speak of the bodily habit, is as it were loosened by ease, and relaxes the energy of his mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:202
verses.text: But the careful watchman, the active searcher, the watchful guardian, who keeps the outposts of the camp, stands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:203
verses.text: The zealous warrior, too, who desires to anticipate the designs of the enemy, stands in array before he is expected.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:205
verses.text: "Let him that standeth take heed lest he fall".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:206
verses.text: He who stands does not give way to detraction, for it is the tales of those at ease in which detraction is spread abroad, and malignity betrayed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:207
verses.text: So that the prophet says: "I have hated the congregation of the malignant, and will not sit with the ungodly".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:208
verses.text: And in the thirty-sixth Psalm, which he has filled with moral precepts, he has put at the very beginning: "Be not malignant amongst the malignant, neither be envious of those who do iniquity".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:209
verses.text: Malignancy is more harmful than malice, because malignancy has neither pure simplicity nor open malice, but a hidden ill-will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:210
verses.text: And it is more difficult to guard against what is hidden than against what is known.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:211
verses.text: For which reason too our Saviour warns us to beware of malignant spirits, because they would catch us by the appearance of sweet pleasures and a show of other things, when they hold forth honour to entice us to ambition, riches to avarice, power to pride.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:213
verses.text: And so both in every action, and especially in the demand for a bishop, by whom [as a pattern] the life of all is formed; malignity ought to be absent; so that the man who is to be elected out of all, and to heal all, may be preferred to all by a calm and peaceful decision.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:214
verses.text: For "the meek man is the physician of the heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:215
verses.text: And the Lord in the Gospel called Himself this, when He said: "They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:217
verses.text: He is the good Physician, Who has taken upon Him our infirmities, has healed our sicknesses, and yet He, as it is written, honoured not Himself to be made a High Priest, but He Who spake to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:218
verses.text: The Father said: "Thou art My Son, this day have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:219
verses.text: As He said in another place: "Thou art a Priest for ever after the order of Melchisedech".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:220
verses.text: Who, since He was the type of all future priests, took our flesh upon Him, that "in the days of His flesh He might offer prayers and supplications with a loud voice and tears; and by those things which He suffered, though He was the Son of God, might seem to learn obedience, which He taught us, that He might be made to us the Author of Salvation".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:221
verses.text: And at last when His sufferings were completed, as though completed and made perfect Himself, He gave health to all, He bore the sin of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:223
verses.text: And so He Himself also chose Aaron as priest, that not the will of man but the grace of God should have the chief part in the election of the priest; not the voluntary offering of himself, nor the taking it upon himself, but the vocation from heaven, that he should offer gifts for sins who could be touched for those who sinned, for He Himself, it is said, bears our weakness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:224
verses.text: No one ought to take this honour upon himself but they are called of God, as was Aaron, and so Christ did not demand but received the priesthood.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:226
verses.text: Lastly, when the succession derived through family descent from Aaron, contained rather heirs of the family than sharers in his righteousness, there came, after the likeness of that Melchisedech, of whom we read in the Old Testament, the true Melchisedech, the true King of peace, the true King of righteousness, for this is the interpretation of the Name, "without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life," which also refers to the Son of God, Who in His Divine Generation had no mother, was in His Birth of the Virgin Mary without a father; begotten before the ages of the Father alone, born in this age of the Virgin alone, and certainly could have no beginning of days seeing He "was in the beginning".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:227
verses.text: And how could He have any end of life, Who is the Author of life to all? He is "the Beginning and the Ending".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:228
verses.text: But this also is referred to Him as an example, that a priest ought to be without father and without mother, since in him it is not nobility of family, but holiness of character and pre-eminence in virtue which is elected.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:230
verses.text: Let there be in him faith and ripeness of character, not one without the other, but let both meet together in one with good works and deeds.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:231
verses.text: For which reason the Apostle Paul wishes that we should be imitators of them, who, as he says, "by faith and patience" possess the promises made to Abraham, who by patience was found worthy to receive and to possess the grace of the blessing promised to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:232
verses.text: David the prophet warns us that we should be imitators of holy Aaron, and has set him amongst the Saints of God to be imitated by us, saying: "Moses and Aaron among his priests, and Samuel among those that call upon His Name".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:234
verses.text: A man clearly worthy to be proposed that all should follow him was he, for when a terrible death on account of the rebels was spreading over the people, he offered himself between the dead and the living, that he might arrest death, and that no more should perish.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:235
verses.text: A man truly of priestly mind and soul, who as a good shepherd with pious affection offered himself for the Lord's flock.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:236
verses.text: And so he broke the sting of death, restrained its violence, refused it further course.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:237
verses.text: Affection aided his deserts, for he offered himself for those who were resisting him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:239
verses.text: Let those then who dissent learn to fear to rouse up the Lord, and to appease His priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:240
verses.text: What! did not the earthquake swallow up Dathan, Abiron, and Korah because of their dissension? For when Korah, Dathan, and Abiron had stirred up two hundred and fifty men against Moses and Aaron to separate themselves from them, they rose up against them and said: "Let it suffice you that all the congregation are holy, every one, and the Lord is amongst them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:242
verses.text: Whereupon the Lord was angry and spoke to the whole congregation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:243
verses.text: The Lord considered and knew those that were His, and drew His saints to Himself; and those whom He chose not, He did not draw to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:244
verses.text: And the Lord commanded that Korah and all those who had risen up with him against Moses and Aaron the priests of the Lord should take to themselves censers, and put on incense, that he who was chosen of the Lord might be established as holy among the Levites of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:246
verses.text: And Moses said to Korah: "Hear me, ye sons of Levi: Is this a small thing unto you, that God hath separated you from the congregation of Israel, and brought you near to Himself, to minister the service of the Tabernacle of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:247
verses.text: And farther on, "Seek ye the priesthood also, so that thou and all thy congregation are gathered against the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:248
verses.text: And what is Aaron that ye murmur about him?"  55.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:249
verses.text: Considering, then, what causes of offence existed, that unworthy persons desired to discharge the offices of the priesthood, and therefore were causing dissensions; and were murmuring in censure of the judgment of God in the choice of His priest, the whole people were seized with a great fear, and dread of punishment came upon them all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:250
verses.text: But when all implore that all perish not for the insolence of few, those guilty of the wickedness are marked out; and two hundred and fifty men with their leaders are separated from the whole body of the people; and then the earth with a groan cleaves asunder in the midst of the people, a deep gulf opens, the offenders are swallowed up, and are so removed from all the elements of this world, as neither to pollute the air by breathing it, nor the heavens by beholding them, nor the sea by their touch, nor the earth by their sepulchres.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:252
verses.text: The punishment ceased, but the wickedness ceased not; for from this very thing a murmuring rose among them that the people had perished through the priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:253
verses.text: In His wrath at this, the Lord would have destroyed them all, had He not been moved first by the prayers of Moses and Aaron, and afterwards also at the intervention of His priest Aaron (the humiliation of their forgiveness being thereby greater), He willed to give their lives to those whose privilege they had repudiated.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:255
verses.text: Miriam the prophetess herself, who with her brothers had crossed the straits of the sea on foot, because, being still ignorant of the mystery of the Ethiopian woman, she had murmured against her brother Moses, broke out with leprous spots, so that she would scarcely have been freed from so great a plague, unless Moses had prayed for her.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:256
verses.text: Although this murmuring refers to the type of the Synagogue, which is ignorant of the mystery of that Ethiopian woman, that is the Church gathered out of the nations, and murmurs with daily reproaches, and envies that people through whose faith itself also shall be delivered  from the leprosy of its unbelief, according to what we read that: "blindness in part has happened unto Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in, and so all Israel shall be saved".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:258
verses.text: And that we may observe that divine grace rather than human works in priests, of the many rods which Moses had received according to the Tribes, and had laid up, that of Aaron alone blossomed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:259
verses.text: And so the people saw that the gift of the Divine vocation is to be looked for in a priest, and ceased from claiming equal grace for a human choice though they had before thought that a similar prerogative belonged to themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:260
verses.text: But what else does that rod show, but that priestly grace never decays, and in the deepest lowliness has in its office the flower of the power committed to it, or that this also is refered to in mystery? Nor do we think that it was without a purpose that this took place near the end of the life of Aaron the priest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:261
verses.text: It seems to be shown that the ancient people, full of decay through the oldness of the long-continued unfaithfulness of the priests, being fashioned again in the last times to zeal in faith and devotion by the example of the Church, will again send forth with revived grace its flowers dead through so many ages.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:263
verses.text: But what does this signify, that after Aaron was dead, the Lord commanded, not the whole people, but Moses alone, who is amongst the priests, to clothe Aaron's son Eleazar with the priest's garments, except that we should understand that priest must consecrate priest, and himself clothe him with the vestments, that is, with priestly virtues; and then, if he has seen that nothing is wanting to him of the priestly garments, and that all things are perfect, should admit him to the sacred altars.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:264
verses.text: For he who is to supplicate for the people ought to be chosen of God and approved by the priests, lest there be anything which might give serious offence in him whose office it is to intercede for the offences of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:265
verses.text: For the virtue of a priest must be of no ordinary kind, since he has to guard not only from nearness to greater faults, but even the very least.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:266
verses.text: He must also be prompt to have pity, not recall a promise, restore the fallen, have sympathy with pain, preserve meekness, love piety, repel or keep down anger, must be as it were a trumpet to excite the people to devotion, or to soothe them to tranquillity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:268
verses.text: It is an old saying: Accustom yourself to be consistent, that your life may set forth as it were a picture, always preserving the same representation which it has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:269
verses.text: How can he be consistent who at one time is inflamed by anger, at another blazes up with fierce indignation, whose face now burns, and now again is changed to paleness, varying and changing colour every moment? But let it be so, let it be natural for one to be angry, or that there is generally a cause, it is a man's duty to restrain anger, and not to be carried away like a lion by fury, so as not to know to be quieted, not to spread tales, nor to embitter family quarrels; for it is written: "A wrathful man diggeth up sin".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:270
verses.text: He will not be consistent who is double-minded; he cannot be consistent who cannot restrain himself when angry, as to which David well says: "Be ye angry and sin not".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:271
verses.text: He does not govern his anger, but indulges his natural disposition, which a man cannot indeed prevent but may moderate.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:272
verses.text: Therefore even though we are angry, let our passion admit only such emotion as is according to nature, not sin contrary to nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:273
verses.text: For who would endure that he should not be able to govern himself, who has undertaken to govern others?  61.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:274
verses.text: And so the Apostle has given a pattern, saying that a bishop must be blameless, and in another place: "A bishop must be without offence, as a steward of God, not proud, not soon angry, not given to wine, not a striker, not greedy of filthy lucre".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:275
verses.text: For how can the compassion of a dispenser of alms and the avarice of a covetous man agree together?  62.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:276
verses.text: I have set down these things which I have been told are to be avoided, but the Apostle is the Master of virtues, and he teaches that gainsayers are to be convicted with patience, who lays down that one should be the husband of a single wife, not in order to exclude him from the right of marriage (for this is beyond the force of the precept), but that by conjugal chastity he may preserve the grace of his baptismal washing; nor again that he may be induced by the Apostle's authority to beget children in the priesthood; for he speaks of having children, not of begetting them, or marrying again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:278
verses.text: And I have thought it well not to pass by this point, because many contend that having one wife is said of the time after Baptism; so that the fault whereby any  obstacle would ensue would be washed away in baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:279
verses.text: And indeed all faults and sins are washed away; so that if anyone have polluted his body with very many whom he has bound to himself by no law of marriage, all the sins are forgiven him, but if any one have contracted a second marriage it is not done away; for sin not law is loosed by the laver, and as to baptism there is no sin but law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:280
verses.text: That then which has to do with law is not remitted as though it were sin, but is retained.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:281
verses.text: And the Apostle has established a law, saying: "If any man be without reproach the husband of one wife".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:282
verses.text: So then he who is without blame the husband of one wife comes within the rule for undertaking the priestly office; he, however, who has married again has no guilt of pollution, but is disqualified for the priestly prerogative.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:284
verses.text: We have stated what is according to the law, let us state in addition what is according to reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:285
verses.text: But first we must notice that not only has the Apostle laid down this rule concerning a bishop or priest, but that the Fathers in the Nicene Council added that no one who has contracted a second marriage ought to be admitted amongst the clergy at all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:286
verses.text: For how can he comfort or honour a widow, or exhort her to preserve her widowhood, and the faith pledged to her husband, which he himself has not kept in regard to his former marriage? Or what difference would there be between people and priest, if they were bound by the same laws? The life of a priest ought to excel that of others as does his grace, for he who binds others by his precepts ought himself to keep the precepts of the law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:288
verses.text: How I resisted my ordination, and lastly, when I was compelled, endeavoured that it might at least be deferred, but the prescribed rule did not prevail against the popular eagerness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:289
verses.text: Yet the Western Bishops approved of my ordination by their decision, the Eastern by an example of the same kind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:290
verses.text: And yet the ordination of a neophyte is forbidden, lest he should be lifted up by pride.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:291
verses.text: If the ordination was not postponed it was because of constraint, and if humility suitable to the priestly office be not wanting, where there is no reason blame will not be imputed to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:293
verses.text: But if so much consideration is needed in other churches for the ordination of a bishop, how much care is required in the Church of Vercellae, where two things seem to be equally required of the bishop, monastic rule and church discipline? For Eusebius of holy memory was the first in Western lands to bring together these differing matters, both while living in the city observing the rules of the monks, and ruling the Church with fasting and temperance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:294
verses.text: For the grace of the priesthood is much increased if the bishop constrain young men to the practice of abstinence, and to the rule of purity; and forbid them though living in the city, the manners and mode of life of the city.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:296
verses.text: From such a rule sprang those great men, Elijah, Elisha, John the son of Elizabeth, who clothed in sheepskins, poor and needy, and afflicted with pain, wandered in deserts, in hollows and thickets of mountains, amongst pathless rocks, rough caves, pitfalls and marshes, of whom the world was not worthy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:297
verses.text: From the same, Daniel, Ananias, Azarias, and Misael, who were brought up in the royal palace, were fed meagrely as though in the desert, with coarse food, and ordinary drink.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:298
verses.text: Rightly did those royal slaves prevail over kingdoms, despise captivity, shaking off its yoke, subdue powers, conquer the elements, quench the nature of fire, dull the flames, blunt the edge of the sword, stop the mouths of lions; they were found most strong when esteemed to be most weak, and did not shrink from the mockings of men, because they looked for heavenly rewards; they did not dread the darkness of the prison, on whom was shining the beauty of eternal light.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:300
verses.text: Following these, holy Eusebius went forth out of his country, and from his own relatives, and preferred a foreign wandering to ease at home.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:301
verses.text: For the faith also he preferred and chose the hardships of exile, in conjunction with Dionysius of holy memory, who esteemed a voluntary exile above an Emperor's friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:302
verses.text: And so these illustrious men, surrounded with arms, closed in by soldiers, when torn away from the larger  Church, triumphed over the imperial power, because by earthly shame they purchased fortitude of soul, and kingly power; they from whom the band of soldiers and the din of arms could not tear away the faith subdued the raging of the brutal mind, which was unable to hurt the saints.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:303
verses.text: For, as you read in Proverbs, "the king's wrath is as the wrath of a lion".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:305
verses.text: He confessed that he was overcome when he asked them to change their determination, but they thought their pen stronger than swords of iron.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:306
verses.text: Then it was unbelief which was wounded so that it fell, not the faith of the saints; they did not desire a tomb in their own country, for whom was reserved a home in the heavens.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:307
verses.text: They wandered over the whole earth, "having nothing and yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:308
verses.text: Wherever they were sent, they esteemed it a place full of delights, for nothing was wanting to them in whom the riches of faith abounded.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:309
verses.text: Lastly, they enriched others, being themselves poor as to earthly means, rich in grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:310
verses.text: They were tried but not killed, in fasting, in labours, in watchings, in vigils.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:311
verses.text: Out of weakness they came forth strong.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:312
verses.text: They did not wait for the enticements of pleasure who were satiated by fasting; the burning summer did not parch those whom the hope of eternal grace refreshed, nor did the cold of icy regions break them down, whose devotion was ever budding afresh with glowing devotion; they feared not the chains of men whom Jesus had set free; they desired not to be rescued from death, who expected to be raised again by Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:314
verses.text: And at last holy Dionysius requested in his prayers, that he might end his life in exile, for fear that he might, if he returned home, find the minds of the people or the clergy disturbed through the teaching or practice of the unbelievers, and he obtained this favour, so that he bore with him the peace of the Lord with a quiet mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:315
verses.text: Thus as holy Eusebius first raised the standard of confessorship, so blessed Dionysius in his exile gave up his life with honour higher even than martyrs.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:317
verses.text: Now this patience in holy Eusebius grew strong by the discipline of the monastery, and from the custom of hard endurance he derived the power of enduring hardships.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:318
verses.text: For who doubts that in stricter Christian devotion these two things are the most excellent, the offices of the clergy and the rule of the monks? The former is a discipline which accustoms to courteousness and good morals, the latter to abstinence and patience; the former as it were on an open stage, the latter in secret; the one is visible, the other hidden.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:319
verses.text: And so he who was a good athlete said: "We are made a spectacle to this world and to Angels".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:320
verses.text: Worthy indeed was he to be gazed upon by Angels, when he was striving to attain the prize of Christ, when he was striving to lead on earth the life of Angels, and overcome the wickedness of spirits in heaven, for he wrestled with spiritual wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:321
verses.text: Rightly did the world gaze upon him, that it might imitate him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:323
verses.text: The one life, then, is on the open arena, the other hidden as in a cave; the one is opposed to the confusion of the world, the other to the desires of the flesh; the one subdues, the other shuns the pleasures of the body; the one was more agreeable, the other more safe; the one ruling, the other restraining itself, in order to be wholly Christ's, for to the perfect it is said: "He who will come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:324
verses.text: Now he follows Christ who is able to say: "It is no longer I that live, but Christ liveth in me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:326
verses.text: Paul denied himself, when, knowing that chains and tribulations awaited him in Jerusalem, he willingly offered himself to danger, saying: "Nor do I count my life dear to myself, if only I can accomplish my course, and the ministry of the Word, which I have received of the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:327
verses.text: And at last, though many were standing round, weeping and beseeching him, he did not change his mind, so stern a censor of itself is ready faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:329
verses.text: The one then contends, the other retires; the one overcomes incitements, the other flees from them; by the one the world is triumphed over, the other rejoices over it; to the one the world is crucified, or itself is crucified to the world, to the other it is unknown; the one endures more frequent temptations, and so has the greater victory, the other falls less often, and keeps guard more easily.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:331
verses.text: Elijah himself too, that the word spoken by his mouth might be confirmed, was sent by the Lord to hide himself by the brook Cherith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:332
verses.text: Ahab threatened, Jezebel threatened, Elijah was afraid and rose up, and then "went in the strength of that spiritual meat forty days and forty nights  unto Horeb the mount of God;" and entered into a cave and rested there; and afterwards was sent to anoint kings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:333
verses.text: He was then inured to patience by dwelling in solitude, and, as though fed to the fatness of virtue by the homely food, went on more strong.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:335
verses.text: John, too, grew up in the desert, and baptized the Lord, and there first practised constancy, that afterwards he might rebuke kings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:337
verses.text: And since in speaking of holy Elijah's dwelling in the desert, we have passed by without notice the names of places which were not given without a purpose, it seems well to go back to what they signify.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:338
verses.text: Elijah was sent to the brook Cherith, and there the ravens nourished him, bringing him bread in the morning, for it "strengthens man's heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:339
verses.text: For how should the prophet be nourished except by mystical food? At evening flesh was supplied.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:340
verses.text: Understand what you read, for Cherith means "understanding," Horeb signifies "heart" or "as a heart," Beersheba also is interpreted "the well of the seventh," or "of the oath".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:342
verses.text: Elijah went first to Beersheba, to the mysteries and sacraments of the divine and holy Law, next he is sent to the brook, to the stream of the river which makes glad the City of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:343
verses.text: You perceive the two Testaments of the One Author; the old Scripture as a well deep and obscure, whence you can only draw with labour; it is not full, for He Who was to fill it was not yet come, Who afterwards said: "I am come not to destroy but to fulfil the Law".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:344
verses.text: And so the Saint is bidden of the Lord to pass over to the stream, for he who has drunk of the New Testament, not only is a river, but also "from his belly shall flow rivers of living water," rivers of understanding, rivers of meditation, spiritual rivers, which, however, dried up in the times of unbelief, lest the sacrilegious and unbelieving should drink.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:346
verses.text: At that place the ravens recognized the Prophet of the Lord, whom the Jews did not recognize.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:347
verses.text: The ravens fed him, whom that royal and noble race were persecuting.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:348
verses.text: What is Jezebel, who persecuted him but the Synagogue, vainly fluent, vainly abounding in the Scriptures, which it neither keeps nor understands? What ravens fed him but those whose young call upon Him, to whose cattle He gives food as we read; "to the young ravens that call upon Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:349
verses.text: Those ravens knew whom they were feeding, who were close upon understanding, and brought food to that stream of sacred knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:351
verses.text: He feeds the prophet, who understands and keeps the things that are written.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:352
verses.text: Our faith gives him sustenance, our progress gives him nourishment; he feeds upon our minds and senses, his discourse is nourished by our understanding.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:353
verses.text: In the morning we give him bread, who, being placed in the light of the Gospel, bestow on him the settled strength of our hearts.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:354
verses.text: By these things he is nourished, by these he is strong, with these he fills the mouths of those who fast, to whom the unbelief of the Jews supplied no food of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:355
verses.text: To them every prophetic utterance is but fasting diet, the interior richness of which they do not see; empty and thin, such as cannot fatten their jaws.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:357
verses.text: Perhaps they brought him flesh in the evening, as it were stronger food, such as the Corinthians, whose minds were weak, could not take, and were therefore fed by the Apostle with milk.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:358
verses.text: So, stronger meat was brought in the evening of the world, in the morning bread.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:359
verses.text: And so, because the Lord commanded this food to be supplied, that word of prophecy may be suitably addressed to Him in this place: "Thou wilt give joy in the outgoings of morning and evening;" and, farther on: "Thou hast prepared their food, for so is its preparation".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:361
verses.text: But I think that enough has been said of the Master, let us now go on to the lives of the disciples, who have given themselves to His praise and celebrate it with hymns day and night.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:362
verses.text: For this is the service of the Angels, to be always occupied in the praises of God, to propitiate and entreat the Lord with frequent prayers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:363
verses.text: They attend to reading, or occupy their minds with continual labours, and separated from the companionship of women, afford safe protection to each other.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:364
verses.text: What a life is this, in which is nothing to fear, much to imitate! The pain of fasting is compensated by tranquillity of mind, is lightened by practice, aided by leisure, or beguiled by occupation; is not burdened with worldly cares, nor occupied with uncongenial troubles, nor weighed down with the distractions of the city.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:366
verses.text: You perceive what kind of teacher must be found for the preservation or teaching of this gift, and we can find him, if you assist by unanimity, if you forgive one  another should any one think himself injured by another.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:367
verses.text: For it is not the only kind of justice, not to injure him who has not injured us, but also to forgive him who has most injured us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:368
verses.text: We are often injured by the fraud of another, by the guile of a neighbour; do we consider it a mark of virtue, to avenge guile by guile, or to repay fraud by fraud? For if justice is a virtue it should be free from offence, and should not repel wickedness by wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:369
verses.text: For what virtue is it that the same thing should be done by you which you yourself punish in another? That is the spreading of wickedness not its punishment, for it makes no difference whom one injures, whether a just man or an unjust, seeing one ought not to injure anyone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:370
verses.text: Nor does it make any difference in what way one bears ill will, whether from a desire of revenging oneself, or from a wish to injure, since in neither case is ill will free from blame.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:371
verses.text: For to bear ill will is the same thing as to be unjust, and so it is said to thee: "Bear not ill will amongst those that bear ill will, and emulate not those that do unrighteousness;" and above; "I have hated the congregation of them that bear ill will".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:372
verses.text: He clearly comprehends all and makes no exception, he lays hold of ill will and asks not the cause.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:374
verses.text: But what better pattern can there be than that of Divine justice? For the Son of God says: "Love your enemies;" and again: "Pray for those that persecute you and speak against you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:375
verses.text: So far does He remove the desire of vengeance from the perfect that He commands charity towards those who injure them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:376
verses.text: And since He had said in the Old Testament: "Vengeance is Mine, I will repay".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:377
verses.text: He says in the Gospel, that we are to pray for those who have injured us, that He Who has said that He will avenge, may not do so; for it is His will to pardon at your desire with which according to His promise He agrees.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:378
verses.text: But if you seek for you know that the unjust is more severely punished by his own convictions than by judicial severity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:380
verses.text: And since no one can be without some adversities, let us take care that they do not happen to us through our own fault.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:381
verses.text: For no one is more severely condemned by the judgment of others, than a foolish man, who is the cause of his misfortunes, is condemned by his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:382
verses.text: For which reason we should decline matters which are full of trouble and contention, which have no advantage, but cause hindrances.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:383
verses.text: Although we ought to take care not to have to repent our decisions or acts.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:384
verses.text: For it is the part of a prudent man to look forward, so as not often to have to repent, for never to repent belongs to God alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:385
verses.text: But what is the fruit of righteousness, but tranquillity of mind? Or what is to live righteously but to live with tranquility? Such as is the pattern of the master, such is the condition of the whole house.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:386
verses.text: But if these things are requisite in a house, how much more in the Church, "where we, both rich and poor, bond and free, Greek and Scythian, noble and common, are all one in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:388
verses.text: Let no man suppose that because he is rich, more deference is to be paid him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:389
verses.text: In the Church he is rich who is rich in faith, for the faithful has a whole world of riches.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:390
verses.text: What wonder is it if the faithful possesses the world, who possesses the inheritance of Christ, which is of more value than the world? "Ye were redeemed with the Precious Blood," was certainly said to all, not to the rich only.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:391
verses.text: But if you will be rich, obey him who says: "Be ye holy in all your conversation".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:392
verses.text: He is speaking not to the rich only but to all; for He judges without respect of persons, as the Apostle His faithful witness says.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:393
verses.text: And therefore says he: "Spend the time of your sojourning here," not in luxury, or fastidiousness, nor haughtiness of heart, but in fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:394
verses.text: On this earth you have time not eternity, do you use the time as those who must pass hence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:396
verses.text: Do not trust in riches; for all such things are left here, faith alone will accompany you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:397
verses.text: And righteousness indeed will go with you if faith has led the way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:398
verses.text: Why do riches entice you? "Ye were not redeemed with gold and silver," with possessions, or silk garments, "from your vain conversation, but with the precious Blood of Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:399
verses.text: He then is rich who is an heir of God, a joint heir with Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:400
verses.text: Despise not the poor man, he has made you rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:401
verses.text: "This poor man cried, and the Lord heard him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:402
verses.text: Do not reject a poor man, Christ when He was rich became poor, and became poor because of you, that by His poverty He might make you rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:403
verses.text: Do not then as though rich exalt yourself, He sent forth His apostles without money.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:405
verses.text: And the first of them said: "Silver and gold have I none".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:406
verses.text: He glories in  poverty as though shunning contamination.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:407
verses.text: "Silver and gold," he says, "I have none,"not gold and silver.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:408
verses.text: He knows not their order in value who knows not the use of them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:409
verses.text: "Silver and gold have I none," but I have faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:410
verses.text: I am rich enough in the Name of Jesus, "which is above every name".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:411
verses.text: I have no silver, neither do I require any; I have no gold, neither do I desire it, but I have what you rich men have not, I have what even you would consider to be of more value, and I give it to the poor, namely that I say in the Name of Jesus: "Be strengthened, ye weak hands, and ye feeble knees".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:413
verses.text: But if you will be rich, you must be poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:414
verses.text: Then shall you in all things be rich, if you are poor in spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:415
verses.text: It is not property which makes rich, but the spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:417
verses.text: There are those who humble themselves in abundance of riches, and they act rightly and prudently, for the law of nature is sufficiently rich for all, according to which one may soon find what is more than enough; but for lust any abundance of riches is still penury.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:418
verses.text: Again, no one is born poor but becomes so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:419
verses.text: Poverty then is not in nature but in our own feelings, and so to find oneself rich is easy for nature, but hard for lust.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:420
verses.text: For the more a man has gained the more he thirsts for gain, and burns as it were with a kind of intoxication from his lusts.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:422
verses.text: Why do you seek for a heap of riches as though it were necessary? Nothing is so necessary as to know that this is not necessary.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:423
