verses.text: Why do you throw the blame on the flesh? It is not the belly in the body but avarice in the mind which makes a man insatiable.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:424
verses.text: Does the flesh take away the hope of the future? Does the flesh destroy the sweetness of spiritual grace? Does the flesh hinder faith? Is it the flesh which attributes any weight to vain opinions as it were to insane masters? The flesh prefers frugal moderation, by which it is freed from burdens, is clothed with health, because it has laid aside its care and has obtained tranquillity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:426
verses.text: But riches themselves are not blameable.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:427
verses.text: For "the ransom of a man's life are his riches," since he that gives to the poor redeems his soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:428
verses.text: So that even in these material riches there is place for virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:429
verses.text: You are like steersmen in the vast sea.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:430
verses.text: If a man steers his course well, he quickly passes over the sea so as to attain to the port, but one who knows not how to direct his property is drowned together with his freight.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:431
verses.text: And so it is written: "The wealth of rich men is a most strong city".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:433
verses.text: And what is that city but Jerusalem which is in heaven, in which is the kingdom of God? This is a good possession which brings eternal fruit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:434
verses.text: A good possession which is not left here, but is possessed there.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:435
verses.text: He who possesses this says: "The Lord is my portion".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:436
verses.text: He says not, My portion stretches and extends from this boundary to that.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:437
verses.text: Nor does he say, My portion is amongst such and such neighbours, except perchance amongst the apostles, amongst the prophets, amongst the saints of the Lord, for this is the righteous man's portion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:438
verses.text: He does not say, My portion is in the meadows, or in the woods, or the plains, except perchance those wooded plains in which the Church is found, of which it is written: "We found it in the wooded plains".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:439
verses.text: He does not say, My portion consists of herds of horses, for "a horse is a vain thing for safety".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:440
verses.text: He does not say, My portion consists of herds of oxen, asses, or sheep; except perchance he reckons himself amongst those which know their Owner, and wishes to company with the ass which does not shun the crib of Christ; and that Sheep is his portion which was led to the slaughter, and that Lamb which was dumb before the shearer, and opened not His mouth, in Whose humiliation judgment has been exalted.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:441
verses.text: Well does he say "before the shearer," for He laid aside what was additional, not His own essence, on the cross, when He laid aside His Body, but lost not His Divinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:443
verses.text: It is not then everyone who can say, "The Lord is my portion".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:444
verses.text: The covetous man cannot, for covetousness draws near and says: Thou art my portion, I have thee in subjection, thou hast served me, thou hast sold thyself to me with that gold, by that possession thou hast adjudged thyself to me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:445
verses.text: The luxurious man says not: Christ is my portion, for luxury comes and says: Thou art my portion, I made thee mine in that banquet, I caught thee in the net of that feast, I hold thee by the bond of thy gluttony.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:446
verses.text: Dost thou not know that thy table was more valued by thee than thy life? I refute thee by thine own judgment, deny if thou canst, but thou canst not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:447
verses.text: And in fine thou hast reserved nothing for thy life, thou hast spent it all for thy table.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:448
verses.text: The adulterer cannot say: "The Lord is my portion;" for lust comes and says: I am  thy portion, thou didst bind thyself to me in the love of that maiden, by a night with that harlot thou hast come under my laws and into my power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:449
verses.text: The traitor cannot say: "Christ is my portion," for at once the wickedness of his sin rushes on him and says: He is deceiving Thee, Lord Jesus, he is mine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:451
verses.text: We have an example of this, for when Judas had received the bread from Christ the devil entered into his heart, as though claiming his own property, as though retaining his right to his own portion, as though saying: He is not Thine but mine; clearly he is my servant, Thy betrayer, plainly he is mine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:452
verses.text: He sits at table with Thee, and serves me; with Thee he feasts, but is fed by me; from Thee he receives bread, from me money; with Thee he drinks, and has sold Thy Blood to me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:453
verses.text: And he proved how truly he spoke.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:454
verses.text: Then Christ departed from him, Judas also himself left Jesus and followed the devil.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:456
verses.text: How many masters has he who has forsaken the One! But let us not forsake Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:457
verses.text: Who would forsake Him Whom they follow bound with chains indeed, but chains of love, which set free and do not bind, those chains in which they who are bound boast, saying: "Paul the bondservant of Jesus Christ, and Timothy".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:458
verses.text: It is more glorious for us to be bound by Him, than to be set free and loosed from others.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:459
verses.text: Who then would flee from peace? Who would flee from salvation? Who would flee from mercy? Who would flee from redemption?  97.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:460
verses.text: You see, my sons, what has been the end of those who followed these things, how being dead they yet work.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:461
verses.text: Let us study to gain the diligence of those the glory of whose virtues we admire, and what we praise in others, let us silently recognize in ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:462
verses.text: Nothing effeminate, nothing feeble attains to praise.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:463
verses.text: "The kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:464
verses.text: The fathers ate the lamb in haste.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:465
verses.text: Faith hastens, devotion is quick, hope is active, it loves not objections of the mind, but to pass from fruitless ease to the fruits of toil.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:466
verses.text: Why do you put off till tomorrow? You can gain to-day; and must guard against not attaining the one and losing the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:467
verses.text: The loss even of one hour is no slight one, one hour is a portion of our whole life.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:469
verses.text: There are young persons who desire quickly to attain to old age, so as no longer to be subject to the will of their elders; and there are also old men who would wish if they could to return again to youth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:470
verses.text: And I approve of neither desire, for the young, disdainful of things present, as it were ungratefully desire a change in their way of living, the old wish for its lengthening, whereas youth can grow old in character, and old age grow green with action.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:471
verses.text: For it is discipline as much as age which brings amendment of character.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:472
verses.text: How much the more then ought we to raise our hopes to the kingdom of God, where will be newness of life, and where will be a change of grace not of age!  99.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:473
verses.text: Reward is not obtained by ease or by sleep.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:474
verses.text: The sleeper does no work, ease brings no profit, but rather loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:475
verses.text: Esau by taking his ease lost the blessing of the first-born, for he preferred to have food given to him rather than to seek it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:476
verses.text: Industrious Jacob found favour with each parent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:478
verses.text: And yet although Jacob was superior in virtue and favour, he yielded to his brother's anger, who grieved that his younger brother was preferred to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:479
verses.text: And so it is written: "Give place to wrath," lest the wrath of another draw you also into sin, when you wish to resist, and to avenge yourself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:480
verses.text: You can put away sin both from him and from yourself, if you think well to yield.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:481
verses.text: Imitate the patriarch who by his mother's counsel went far away.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:482
verses.text: And who was the mother? Rebecca, that is, Patience.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:483
verses.text: For who but Patience could have given this counsel? The mother loved her son, but preferred that he should be cut off from herself rather than from God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:484
verses.text: And so because the mother was good, she benefited both her sons, but to the youngest she gave a blessing which he could keep; yet she preferred not one son to the other as sons; but the active to the easy-going, the faithful to the unbelieving.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:486
verses.text: And so since he was separated from his parents through piety not on account of impiety, he talked with God, he increased in riches, in children, and in favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:487
verses.text: Nor was he elated by these things when he met his brother; but humbly bowed down to him, not indeed considering him the pitiless, the furious, the degenerate, but Him Whom he reverenced in him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:488
verses.text: And so he bowed down seven times, which is the number of remission, for he was not bowing down to man, but to Him Whom he foresaw in the Spirit, as hereafter to come in human flesh to take away the sins of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:489
verses.text: And this mystery is unfolded to you in the answer  given to Peter, when he said: "If my brother trespass against me how often shall I forgive him? Until seven times?" You see that remission of sins is a type of that great Sabbath, of that rest of everlasting grace, and therefore is given by contemplation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:491
verses.text: But what is the meaning of his having arranged his wives and children and all his servants, and ordered that they should bow down to the earth? It was certainly not to the element of earth, which is often filled with blood, in which is the workshop of all crimes, which often is rough with huge rocks, or broken cliffs, or barren and hungry soil, but as to that Flesh which is to be for our salvation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:492
verses.text: And perchance this is that mystery which the Lord taught, when He said: "Not only seven times, but even seventy times seven".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:494
verses.text: Do you then forgive injuries done to you that you may be children of Jacob.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:495
verses.text: Be not provoked as was Esau.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:496
verses.text: Imitate holy David, who as a good master left us what we should follow, saying: "Instead of loving me they spake against me, but I prayed," and when he was reviled, he prayed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:497
verses.text: Prayer is a good shield, wherewith contumely is kept away, cursing is repelled and often is turned back on those who utter it, so that they are wounded by their own weapons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:498
verses.text: "Let them curse," he says, "but bless Thou".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:499
verses.text: The curse of man is to be sought for, which procures the blessing of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:501
verses.text: And for the rest, most dear brethren, consider that Jesus suffered without the gate, and do you go forth out of this earthly city, for your city is Jerusalem which is above.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:502
verses.text: Let your conversation be there, that you may say: "But our conversation is in heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:503
verses.text: Therefore did Jesus go forth out of the city, that you going out of this world may be above the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:504
verses.text: Moses alone, who saw God, had his tabernacle without the camp when he talked with God; and the blood indeed of the victims which were offered for sin, was brought to the altar, but the bodies were burnt without the camp; for no one placed amidst the evil of this world can lay aside sin, nor is his blood accepted of God, except he go forth from the defilement of this body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:506
verses.text: Love hospitality, whereby holy Abraham found favour, and received Christ as his guest, and Sarah already worn with age gained a son; Lot also escaped the fire of the destruction of Sodom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:507
verses.text: You too can receive Angels if you offer hospitality to strangers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:508
verses.text: What shall I say of Rahab who by this means found safety?  106.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:509
verses.text: Compassionate those who are bound with chains, as though bound with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:510
verses.text: Comfort those in sorrow; for, "It is better to go into the house of mourning than into the house of rejoicing".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:511
verses.text: From the one is gained the merit of a good work, from the other a lapse into sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:512
verses.text: Lastly, in the one case you still hope for the reward, in the other you have already received it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:513
verses.text: Feel with those who are afflicted as if also afflicted with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:515
verses.text: Let a wife show deference, not be a slave to her husband; let her show herself ready to be ruled not coerced.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:516
verses.text: She is not worthy of wedlock who deserves chiding.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:517
verses.text: Let a husband also guide his wife like a steersman, honour her as the partner of his life, share with her as a joint heir of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:519
verses.text: Mothers, wean your children, love them, but pray for them that they may long live above this earth, not on the earth but above it, for there is nothing long-lived on this earth, and that which lasts long is but short and very frail.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:520
verses.text: Warn them rather to take up the Cross of the Lord than to love this life.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:522
verses.text: Mary, the mother of the Lord stood by her Son's Cross; no one has taught me this but the holy Evangelist St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:523
verses.text: John.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:524
verses.text: Others have related how the earth was shaken at the Lord's passion, the sky was covered with darkness, the sun withdrew itself; that the thief was after a faithful confession received into paradise.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:525
verses.text: John tells us what the others have not told, how the Lord fixed on the Cross called to His mother, esteeming it of more worth that, victorious over His sufferings, He rendered her the offices of piety, than that He gave her a heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:526
verses.text: For if it be according to religion to grant pardon to the thief, it is a mark of much greater piety that a mother is honoured with such affection by her Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:527
verses.text: "Behold," He says, "thy Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:528
verses.text: "Behold thy mother".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:529
verses.text: Christ testified from the Cross, and divided the offices of piety between the mother and the disciple.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:530
verses.text: The Lord made not only a public but also a private testament, and John signed this testament of His, a witness worthy of so great a Testator.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:531
verses.text: A good testament not of money but of eternal life, which was written not with ink but with  the Spirit of the living God, Who says: "My tongue is the pen of a quickly writing scribe".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:533
verses.text: Nor was Mary below what was becoming the mother of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:534
verses.text: When the apostles fled, she stood at the Cross, and with pious eyes beheld her Son's wounds, for she did not look for the death of her Offspring, but the salvation of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:535
verses.text: Or perchance, because that "royal hall" knew that the redemption of the world would be through the death of her Son, she thought that by her death also she might add something to the public weal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:536
verses.text: But Jesus did not need a helper for the redemption of all, Who saved all without a helper.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:537
verses.text: Wherefore also He says: "I am become like a man without help, free among the dead".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:538
verses.text: He received indeed the affection of His mother, but sought not another's help.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:540
verses.text: Imitate her, holy mothers, who in her only dearly beloved Son set forth so great an example of maternal virtue; for neither have you sweeter children, nor did the Virgin seek the consolation of being able to bear another son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:542
verses.text: Masters, command your servants not as being below you in rank, but as remembering that they are sharers of the same nature as yourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:543
verses.text: Servants, serve your masters with good will, for each ought patiently to support that to which he is born, and be obedient not only to good but also to froward masters.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:544
verses.text: For what thanks has your service if you zealously serve good masters? But if you thus serve the froward also you gain merit; for the free also have no reward, if when they transgress they are punished by the judges, but this is their merit to suffer without transgressing.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:545
verses.text: And so you, if contemplating the Lord Jesus you serve even difficult masters with patience, will have your reward.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:546
verses.text: Since the Lord Himself suffered, the just at the hand of the unjust, and by His wonderful patience nailed our sins to His Cross, that he who shall imitate Him may wash away his sins in His Blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:548
verses.text: In fine, turn all to the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:549
verses.text: Let your enjoyment of this life be with a good conscience, your endurance of death with the hope of immortality, your assurance of the resurrection through the grace of Christ; let truth be with simplicity, faith with confidence, abstinence with holiness, industry with soberness, conversation with modesty, learning without vanity; let there be soberness of doctrine, faith without the intoxication of heresy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter LXIII 1:550
verses.text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all, Amen.
